Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Employing a New Class of Chemosensors for Continuous, Real-Time Measurement of Heavy Metals in Wastewater
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project uses a new class of chemosensor films to continuously measure the concentration of heavy metals in a flowing stream of industrial wastewater. This will make it possible to know the concentration of several heavy metals at any given time so that treatment chemicals used to remove those metals can be metered precisely. Current treatment methods typically rely on infrequent sampling of wastewater streams and time-delayed, labor-intensive laboratory measurements. Without the ability to measure continuously, wastewater treatment is adjusted based on periodic averages and estimated peak discharges. To reduce the risk of regulatory violation, most wastewater treatment systems use twice the volume of treatment chemicals than might otherwise be needed. With the ability to measure metal concentrations continuously and automatically, wastewater treatment can be controlled in real time, cutting treatment chemical costs, solid waste costs and measurement labor costs by more than 50%. Continuous measurement also reduces the risk of regulatory violations by > 90%, in turn reducing the potential costs of remediation and compliance as well as improving environmental conditions for the general public.

The key outcome of Phase I research was the successful development of 15 new chemosensors permanently bound to a substrate, each with a unique response to zinc, cadmium, cobalt, chromium, lead, copper, iron, magnesium, manganese, mercury, nickel and tin. In Phase II, responses from an array of chemosensors will be fully characterized with a prototype instrument developed for commercial use in different industrial environments. With that instrument, a mathematical model will be constructed to accurately convert sensor responses into scientific units of measure for multiple dissolved metals. The lower limit of detection for existing sensors ranges from 5 ppb to 50 ppb. In parallel with analytical modeling work, chemosensor synthesis work continues to lower the limit of detection to 1 ppb, extend sensor life beyond 6 months, and broaden the portfolio of sensors to improve metal selectivity. In the future, this new class of bonded chemosensors may be extended to determine the concentration of phosphates and many other species that are currently sampled occasionally and measured with lab instruments. For applications where continuous measurement is important, this unique family of chemosensors offers great potential for real-time process control in a variety of industrial applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NSF Phase II project, AquaMetals LLC wanted to find a way to measure, in real-time, the concentration of dissolved heavy metals in flowing water.  By employing real-time, continuous monitoring, businesses that are required to limit the discharge of specific metals into public waterways could more confidently follow regulations while at the same time reduce the cost of removing those metals from the water supply.  To achieve this real-time measurement capability, AquaMetals worked with graduate students from the University of Wisconsin to develop a family of azo-dye sensors covalently bound to a polymer substrate. Different azo dye sensors were sensitive to different heavy metals, making it possible to optically distinguish one metal from another. AquaMetals employed these sensors into measurement systems it developed specifically to maximize sensor sensitivity to specific metals and to translate their spectral response over time into accurate units of measure. Resolution of 1 part per billion was achieved with several metals.  Methods were developed to quickly regenerate and recalibrate sensors that became saturated. These conditioning processes allowed sensors to be used continuously for many months before replacement was needed.  In parallel with this work, a cost effective commercial instrument that could be employed in real-world conditions was designed and manufactured to measure the concentration of zinc, lead, copper, cobalt, chromium, nickel, cadmium, and other metals regulated by law to keep the environment safe.

Over the course of the project, many experiments were run by AquaMetals to validate that the measurement system would work in real world conditions. The measurement model worked well over a wide range of pH, salinity and temperature.  Simple salts did not have an adverse effect on the measurement. The experimental evidence developed at the university made it clear that the best way to build quantitative measurement models was to record the sensor response to one metal at a time and then combine the models to obtain selective information about the concentration of different metals. Unfortunately, the one case that could not be tested until the full measurement system was completely integrated was the quantitative effect of metal-metal interactions. System tests demonstrated that if there was only one heavy metal in the sample solution, quantitative accuracy of 5 to 10 parts per billion could be achieved. However, when two or more metals were present in the same sample solution, quantitative errors were extremely large for all metals present.  In the industrial market, wastewater contains many different metals and although the AquaMetals measurement system could easily detect the presence of metals in general, the interference presented by metal-metal interaction made it impossible to provide reliable and accurate concentration values.  Therefore, the product cannot currently meet the market requirements for commercialization as it is unable to provide meaningful feedback in controlling waste treatment.

Research will continue at the University of Wisconsin to develop more selective covalently bound azo dye sensors and to develop more complex models that include an array of selective sensors.  If the metal-metal interference problem can be successfully addressed through further basic science research, the commercial instrument developed during this project may then be employed.
